{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Vladimir P. Peftiev | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_upright = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = Владимир Павлович Пефтиев | native_name_lang = Russian | pronunciation = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1957|07|01}} | birth_place = [[Berdyansk]], Ukrainian SSR | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | burial_place = | burial_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | citizenship = Belarus | education = [[Dnipropetrovsk National University of Rail Transport]] | occupation = Businessman | years_active = Since 1988 | era = | employer = | organization = | known_for = | style = | home_town = | net_worth = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = Olga Makarova | partner = | children = 5 | parents = | mother = | father = | relatives = | family = | callsign = | awards = | website = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} {{more citations needed|date=March 2018}} '''Vladimir Pavlovich Peftiev''' ({{lang-be|Уладзiмiр Паўлавiч Пефцiеў}}; {{lang-ru|link=no|Владимир Павлович Пефтиев}}, born 1 July 1957) is a Belarusian businessman, investor and philanthropist. == Biography == Vladimir Pavlovich Peftiev was born on 1 July 1957 in the city of [[Berdyansk]], Ukraine.[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?qid=1519425050511&uri=CELEX:32011R0588 Council Regulation (EU) No 588/2011 of 20 June 2011 amending Regulation (EC) No 765/2006 concerning restrictive measures against President Lukashenko and certain officials of Belarus] He was educated in the Ukraine at the Institute of Railway Transport Engineers (currently [[Dnipropetrovsk National University of Rail Transport]]), graduating in 1979 with a diploma in electromechanical engineering.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} From 1979 till 1988 he worked with [[Belarusian Railway]] and then with [[Minsk Metro]] as chief engineer, following which in 1988 he began a career in private business.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} == Business == === Overview === Peftiev's business interests since leaving [[Minsk Metro]] have included technological development, special equipment and military exports, telecommunications, medical technology, IT- technology, and sports{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} * 1989–1992: regenerated polymer processing (Plastpribor, a cooperative){{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} * 1993–2012: export of special purpose equipment and technologies including military equipment (BelTechExport){{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} * 1998–2007: mobile phone services ([[Velcom]]), now owned by Telekom Austria Group{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} * 1998–2015: data transmission (Delovaya Set/Business Network){{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} * 2006–present: telecommunications, real estate development, technological development (BT Telecommunications){{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} * 2007–present: interactive electronic games (ZAO Sport-pari){{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} During the past few years, Peftiev has disposed of some of his business assets, including his shareholding in BelTechExport and Delovaya Set, and restructured his remaining business interests.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} He now owns 31% of Sport Pari, with the remainder held by a company belonging to the family of well-known tennis player and 2012 Olympic Champion Maxim Mirnyi.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} == Controversies, criticism == ===EU sanctions=== In 2011, after the wave of repressions that followed the [[Belarusian presidential election, 2010|2010 presidential election in Belarus]], the [[Council of the European Union]] listed Peftiev and his three companies [[BelTechExport]], Sport Pari and BT Telecommunications as sanctioned entities.[https://nn.by/?c=ar&i=61552 Поўны спіс 208 беларускіх чыноўнікаў, якім забаронены ўезд у ЕС] – [[Nasha Niva]], 11 October 2011 In the Council's decision, Peftiev has been described as follows:{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32014D0750|title=COUNCIL DECISION 2011/357/CFSP of 20 June 2011 amending Decision 2010/639/CFSP concerning restrictive measures against certain officials of Belarus|date=20 June 2011|publisher=[[EUR-Lex]]|accessdate=7 November 2017}} {{Quote|[A] person associated with President Lukashenko and his family. Chief economic advisor of President Lukashenko and key financial sponsor of the Lukashenko regime. Chairman of the Council of Shareholders of Beltechexport, the largest export/import company of defence products in Belarus}} Peftiev protested the Council's decision in the [[General Court (European Union)|General Court]] of the European Union.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} The team that defended Vladimir Peftiev in court included world famous specialists in the field of human rights, including: professor of Yale University and former President of Inter-American Commission on Human Rights Michael Reisman and former Director of International Law department of University of Bonn, General Director of the office of the Chancellor of Germany Helmut Kohl from 1992 to 1996, professor Rudolf Dolzer.{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/36638383/The_Aim_of_Sanctions_is_to_Hurt|title=The Aim of Sanctions is to Hurt|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}} At the end of October 2014, before the case had been decided, the sanctions were dropped by the EU Council.http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32014D0750 On 9 December 2014, the General Court of European Union decided in Peftiev’s and his companies’ favour, annulling the sanctions and ruling that the Council of the European Union and European Commission had made serious mistakes while evaluating Peftiev's business activities.http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=160487&pageIndex=0&doclang=EN&mode=lst&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=24475, part 7, "The plea in law concerning manifest errors of assessment," articles 148–206. That was mentioned by professor Dolzer in his interview on May 8, 2018 to Latvian newspaper “Dienas bizness”, in which he pointed out to the false information in the Internet that was used against Vladimir Peftiev, and namely with regard to illegal incomes of Mr. Peftiev, his Forbes rating, weapons exports to North Korea, Ivory Coast and China, his sponsoring of Lukashenko.{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/36638383/The_Aim_of_Sanctions_is_to_Hurt|title=The Aim of Sanctions is to Hurt|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}} The Council did not appeal the Court's decision.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} The European General Court’s judgment of 9 December 2014 concerning Peftiev reads, in part (clause 149):{{Cite web|url=http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=160486&pageIndex=0&doclang=EN&mode=lst&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=24560|title=CURIA – Documents|last=|first=|date=|website=curia.europa.eu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} {{Quote|the Court held that [the sanctions involving Belarus] should be annulled in so far as they concern Mr Peftiev. By virtue of that annulling judgment, the annulled acts, in so far as they concern Mr Peftiev, are deleted retroactively from the legal order and deemed never to have existed … and consequently Mr Peftiev is deemed never to have been listed.}} This decision of European General Court was left unattended by mass media. Moreover, various sources continued to publish disproved information that originated before or during of sanctions, instead of deleting it from their servers according to the court’s decision. This was described by Professor Rudolf Dolzer in his article «Weeding Out Fake Journalism» for 10th issue of Forbes Georgia{{cite web|url=http://forbes.ge/news/4899/Weeding-Out-Fake-Journalism|title=Weeding Out Fake Journalism|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}}{{cite web|url=http://forbes.ge/news/4883/Forbes-Georgia-in-English-10|title=Forbes Georgia in English - Issue #10|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}}: {{Quote|Notwithstanding this clear decision, published in 2014, many concerned Internet sources, including respected data information providers, have decided, for whatever reason, to ignore the highest European Court, and still today, in 2018, have on their servers the outdated, discredited information. Another aspect of fake news has come out. A portion of the media ignored the judgment of the European Court of Justice in favor of Mr. Peftiev, even though the original fake news underlying the sanctions had been published in virtually all media. While fake news was considered newsworthy, its refutation by the court went unnoticed by the same media.{{cite web|url=http://forbes.ge/news/4899/Weeding-Out-Fake-Journalism|title=Weeding Out Fake Journalism|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}} }} ===Offshores=== Pevtiev was mentioned in the Bahamas offshore leaks in 2016: allegedly, he held three companies in Bahamas through an intermediary.{{cite web|url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/world/69839/belarus_dictators_bagman_vladimir_peftiev_once_a_malta_resident_named_in_bahamas_offshore_leaks#.WgLBWthRWUk|title=Belarus dictator’s ‘bagman’ Vladimir Peftiev, once a Malta resident, named in ICIJ’s Bahamas offshore leaks|date=21 September 2016|publisher=[[Malta Today]]|accessdate=8 November 2017}} == Science and technology == During his career to date, Peftiev has contributed research and development to a number of new technologies in mechanical engineering and medicine, of which fourteen have been awarded patents under his name.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} In his research and development work, Peftiev has cooperated with such Belarusian scientists as Vladimir Alexandrovich Katko and Sergey Vladimirovich Pletnev.{{cite web|url=https://patents.google.com/patent/US20150343232|title=Method of combined treatment of maligant tumors|date=|publisher=[[Google Patents]]}} == Philanthropy == Peftiev supports a variety of social, cultural and religious-heritage projects.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} === Sport === In 1995, Peftiev founded a youth tennis club in Minsk which he financed and continued to support until 2011.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} The club helped to recruit highly qualified trainers for talented up-and-coming players, and provided financial assistance and a sports centre to promote national youth tennis.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} Peftiev was the main sponsor of [[Victoria Azarenka]], Olympic tennis champion and former world No. 1, at the beginning of her career.{{Cite web|url=http://sport.tut.by/news/tennis/391282.html|title=Interview of Azarenka's coach|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}} From 2009 to 2012, Peftiev also headed the Belarus Tennis Federation.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pressball.by/news/tennis/104749|title=Tennis. Shakutin replaces Peftiev as head of Belarus Tennis Federation|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}}{{Cite web|url=https://news.tut.by/sport/145028.html|title=Belarus Tennis Federation is now headed by director of BelTechExport|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}} === Religious heritage === Peftiev's contributions to the preservation of Orthodox Christian heritage have been recognised with awards from the Orthodox Church. Since 1998, he has been a member of the Tutorial Board for construction of the Orthodox Church of All Saints and Innocent Victims in Minsk (under the aegis of the [[Belarusian Orthodox Church]]). He assisted in the construction of the House of Mercy in Minsk and is a leading sponsor of the Nikolsky Orthodox Church in Tonezh (completed 2015), built to commemorate the site of a Nazi atrocity.{{Cite web|url=http://news.tut.by/economics/453243.html|title=Peftiev funded renovation of Church|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.pravoslavie.ru/english/79551.htm|title=Memorial church on the cite of the original one burned down by Nazis is consecrated in Belarus|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.patriarchia.ru/db/text/4096415.html|title=A memorial church on the site of one burned down by Nazis with believers inside is consecrated in Belorussian village Tonezh|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}} During 2012–2015, Peftiev sponsored the mural paintings in St John the Baptist's Church of the Monastery of the Holy Ascension in Barkalabovo (Belarus) carried out by students and professors of the Monumental Art Department of the [[Belarusian State Academy of Arts]] in a team headed by Belarusian artist Vladimir Zinkevich.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} Vladimir Peftiev is a Chevalier of Orders of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], a Chevalier of the Order of the Belorussian Orthodox Church, and has also been decorated by the Orthodox Metropolitan of Switzerland.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} === History and the arts === {{more citations needed|section|date=March 2018}} Peftiev has sponsored and in some cases co-authored{{Cite web|url=http://www.kurier.lt/slavnoe-imya/|title=Glorious name|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}} a number of art and historical publications, chiefly in the historical series В поисках утраченного [‘In search of the lost’] by Belorussian historian Vladimir Lihodedov,{{Cite web|url=http://zviazda.by/be/news/20160815/1471274328-uladzimir-lihadzedau-maru-stvaryc-pryvatny-muzey-knigadrukavannya|title=Уладзімір Ліхадзедаў: "Мару стварыць прыватны музей кнігадрукавання"|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}} volumes of which include: * "Tadeusz Kosciuszko", on the political and military leader who contributed to the establishment of freedom and democracy in Europe and America, a copy of which was presented to the US Library of Congress on 4 July 2011 {{ISBN|978-985-458-218-4}}; * "Belarus through the camera lens of the German soldier", on the period during WWI when part of modern Belarus was occupied by German troops {{ISBN|978-985-458-174-3}}; * "[[Adam Mickiewicz]]", on the poet and patriot of Belarus, Poland and Lithuania {{ISBN|978-985-458-177-4}}; * "[[Alexander Nevsky|Aleksander Nevsky]]", on the Orthodox churches built in European countries in honor of the Russian saint-prince {{ISBN|978-985-458-210-8}}; * "State Bank of the Russian Empire in postcards, late 19th-early 20th centuries" {{ISBN|978-985-458-202-3}}; * "Monuments dedicated to the Patriotic War of 1812" {{ISBN|978-985-458-230-6}}. Peftiev has also co-authored: * "The Patriotic War of 1812 in old cards and drawings", a commemoration of the two-hundredth anniversary of the Russian Campaign of Napoleon I and the Russian Patriotic War of 1812{{Cite web|url=http://natbookcat.org.by/isgbi/marcview.do?id=962374&position=1|title=National book chamber of Belarus|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}} {{ISBN|978-985-458-231-3}}; * "Equal-to-the-Apostles Duke Vladimir" (Святой Равноапостольный князь Владимир){{Cite web|url=http://www.eparhia992.by/item/2391-polotskuyu-eparkhiyu-posetil-upolnomochennyj-po-delam-religij-i-natsionalnostej-respubliki-belarus|title=Polotsk eparchy visited by Religions and Nationalities Secretary of Belarus|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sb.by/kultura/article/slavnoe-imya.html|title=Glorious name|author=|work=|date=|publisher=}} {{ISBN|978-985-575-057-5}}. In 2017 a book of maxims by Vladimir Peftiev titled "Maxims of a Man of Schemes"{{Cite web|url=http://www.akkadiapress.uk.com/our-books/maxims-man-schemes/|title=Akkadia Press|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://isbnsearch.org/isbn/9780995689046|title=ISBN|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} was published with a foreword by the British philosopher and author [[A. C. Grayling]]. The foreword says:
These striking, amusing and sometimes pungent aphorisms are so full of a certain kind of pragmatic wisdom that I am moved to quote Professor Higgins on Mr Alfred Doolittle: that the latter was "the most original moralist" that the former had encountered for many years. The hard truths of practical life are apt to wring from people of experience a view of how to navigate the maze of routes that lies between desire and success; it is not, invariably, a view for the faint-hearted or those persuaded more by Aristotle than Gordon Gekko; but it will certainly strike a chord with many who have ventured that maze, and will certainly provide a preparation – and for some a warning – to those planning or wishing to do so. No-one can fail to profit, therefore – in at least one relevant sense of that term – from these maxims, offered by one who has been all the way through that maze and back.
Peftiev’s contributions are helping to preserve the memory of Belarusian soldiers and fighters who fell in the Polish and Lithuanian uprisings of the nineteenth century, the Russian-French War of 1812 (the [[Patriotic War of 1812]]), and the First and [[World War II|Second World Wars]]. Thousands of unique artifacts, photographs, documents and letters have been collected so far, and in 2012 an exhibition at the Belarusian State Museum made many visible to the public.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} Other publications supported by Peftiev in recent years have included books and albums of the work of Belarusian artists Vladimir Zinkevich, Alexander Slucky, Viktor Alshevsky, and celebrated ballet choreographer Valentin Elizarev.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} In 1999, Peftiev's companies partnered with Elizarev and the French Embassy in Belarus to produce the ballet ''[[La Esmeralda (ballet)|La Esmeralda]]'' (inspired by Victor Hugo's ''[[The Hunchback of Notre-Dame|Notre Dame de Paris]]'') at The National Academic Grand Opera and Ballet Theatre of the Republic of Belarus.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} For several years, Peftiev's companies also sponsored the Yuri Bashmet International Music Festival in Minsk and the Belarusian vocal quintet Clear Voice.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} ==See also== * [[List of people and organizations sanctioned in relation to human rights violations in Belarus]] == References == ==External links== * http://europeansanctions.com/2014/12/11/eu-general-court-annuls-4-belarus-sanctions-listings/ Overview of the sanctions decision and European General Court ruling * http://ej.by/rating/business2016/peftiev.html 2016 Belarus business listings, showing Vladimir Peftiev ranking eleventh; some biographical information * http://www.kurier.lt/zapechatlennye-momenty-slavy/ Description of ‘The Patriotic War of 1812 in old cards and drawings’, co-authored by Peftiev * http://mk.by/2012/10/19/71483/ In-depth interview with Vladimir Lihodedov, Peftiev’s co-author * http://tv.sb.by/culture-2/article/authors-united-by-common-interests.html Review of the volume on St. Vladimir * http://times.sb.by/culture-2/article/through-eyes-of-old-postcards.html Review of the volume on St. Vladimir * http://www.belaruspartisan.org/life/362665/ Belarusian businessmen and their collecting hobbies {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Peftiev, Vladimir}} [[Category:Belarusian businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Berdyansk]] [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox officeholder ||name = William Temple Thomson Mason | image = | caption = |state_delegate = Virginia |district = [[Loudoun County, Virginia|Loudoun]] | term_start = December 3, 1842 | term_end = December 1, 1844 | preceded = [[James McIlhaney]] | alongside= Humphrey B. Powell, Samuel B.T. Caldwell | succeeded = [[James McIlhaney]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1782|7|24}} |birth_place = [[Raspberry Plain]], [[Leesburg, Virginia|Leesburg]], Virginia | death_date = 1862 |death_place = [[Georgetown, Washington, D.C.|Georgetown]], Washington, D.C. | resting_place = Old Episcopal Churchyard, Leesburg, Virginia | occupation = planter, politician |alma_mater = [[The College of William & Mary]] | party= | spouse =Ann Eliza Carroll | children =11 |relations = nephew of [[George Mason|George Mason IV]] | residence = | religion = |allegiance= }}
'''William Temple Thomson Mason''' (July 24, 1782–1862)<ref name=GH1>{{cite web | url=http://www.gunstonhall.org/masonweb/p26.htm#i1299 | title=William Temple Thomson Mason | accessdate=February 17, 2008 | publisher=Gunston Hall | author=[[Gunston Hall]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080211141639/http://www.gunstonhall.org/masonweb/p26.htm#i1299 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = February 11, 2008}}</ref> was a prominent [[Virginia]] farmer and businessman.
==Early life== William Temple Thomson Mason was born on July 24, 1782 at [[Raspberry Plain]]. "Temple", as his family called him, was [[Thomson Mason]]'s third child and youngest son with his second wife Elizabeth Westwood Wallace.<ref name=GH1/><ref name="NRHP2">{{cite web | url=http://www.dhr.virginia.gov/registers/Counties/Loudoun/053-0012_Catoctin_Rural_Historic_District_1989_DRAFT_Nomination.pdf | title=National Register of Historic Places Registration Form: Catoctin Rural Historic District | date= December 13, 1988| accessdate=February 17, 2008 | publisher=Virginia Department of Historic Resources | author=Eugene M. Scheel & John S. Salmon}}</ref> He was named after his father’s English cousin, Sir William Temple.<ref name="NRHP2"/> While Temple was still an infant, Temple's father died on February 26, 1785 and he was raised by his mother and older half-brothers.<ref name=GH1/><ref name="NRHP2"/>
At the age of 19, Temple was sent to the [[College of William and Mary]] to obtain a gentleman’s education.<ref name="NRHP2"/> He spent two years at the college, graduating in 1803.<ref name="NRHP2"/> Having reached the legal age of 21, Temple received a parcel of land in northern Loudoun County near [[Leesburg, Virginia|Leesburg]] not far from Raspberry Plain, the house in which he grew up.<ref name="NRHP2"/> According to Thomson Mason's last will and testament, recorded in [[Stafford County, Virginia|Stafford County]] on September 26, 1784, he had bequeathed to Temple, his brother Westwood Thomson Mason and their half-brother, Abram Barnes Thomson Mason, several hundred acres of land along the [[Potomac River]].<ref name="NRHP2"/> On November 29, 1803,<ref name="NRHP2"/> at the [[Loudoun County Courthouse]] in Leesburg, the three brothers filed a document which partitioned the land, with Temple receiving {{convert|757|acre|km2}}.<ref name="NRHP2"/>
==Family and career== Temple Mason built his home, [[Temple Hall]], in the [[Federal architecture|Federal style]] between 1810 and 1812. On June 16, 1812, Temple married Ann Eliza Carroll, daughter of Nicholas Maccubbin Carroll and Anne Jennings, in [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]], Maryland.<ref name=GH1/><ref name="NRHP2"/> Their first child, Temple Anna, was born at Temple Hall in 1813.<ref name=GH1/><ref name="NRHP2"/>
Temple Mason not only oversaw the management of his prosperous Temple Hall farm, but also became involved in the community life of Leesburg.<ref name="NRHP2"/> He served as a [[vestryman]] at [[St. James Episcopal Church (Leesburg, Virginia)|St. James Episcopal Church]] and oversaw the [[polling station|polls]] during elections in Loudoun County.<ref name="NRHP2"/> As a mark of his increased social standing in the community, Temple's estate became a hub of Leesburg society.<ref name=HMDB2/> On August 9, 1825 [[Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette]] during his [[Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette#Grand tour of America|grand tour]] of the United States and accompanied by [[President of the United States|President]] [[John Quincy Adams]] and former President [[James Monroe]] (who was then residing at his [[Oak Hill (James Monroe House)|Oak Hill]] [[plantations in the American South|plantation]] in southern Loudoun County) visited Temple Hall.<ref name="NRHP2"/> The three gentlemen witnessed the [[baptism]] of Mason's two youngest daughters; Lafayette became the godfather for Mary Carroll, and Adams and Monroe became as Maria Louisa's godfathers.<ref name="NRHP2"/><ref name="NRHP2"/><ref name=HMDB2>{{cite web | url=http://www.hmdb.org/Marker.asp?Marker=12954 | title=Temple Hall | date=October 25, 2008 | accessdate=February 17, 2008 | publisher=Historical Marker Database | author=[[Northern Virginia Regional Park Authority]]}}</ref>
Mason served one term in the Virginia House of Delegates, from 1830-1831, temporarily displacing veteran [[James McIlhaney]].<ref>Cynthia Miller Leonard, The Virginia General Assembly 1619-1978 (Virginia State Library 1978) p. 356</ref>
Two of Temple Mason's sons and one of his daughters, Templeanna (1819-1849), died before the American Civil War. The same Leesburg, Virginia graveyard contains the remains of his sons Thomas Henry Carroll Mason (1822-1838) and Westwood Thomson Mason (1819-1854), the latter of whom died in [[Savannah, Georgia]]. Charles Carroll Mason (d. 1866) and Nicholas Carroll Mason (1810 - 1874) did not serve in either army in that conflict and are also buried in that cemetery; likewise William Temple Thomson Mason, Jr. (1800-1891), who would die and be buried in Tennessee. William T.T. Mason's daughter Eliza Mason Welch (1820-1899) married in Maryland in 1836 but spent most of her adult years and died in Iowa. In the 1850 U.S. Federal census, Mason owned more than a dozen enslaved people.<ref>In the 1850 U.S. Federal Census slave schedule, Loudoun County, Virginia, William Mason owned a dozen enslaved people and Thompson Mason owned at least 35</ref> William T.T. Mason of Washington, D.C. owned at least four enslaved people in 1860, a 5 year old black girl, 16 year old mulatto woman and 30 and 59 year old black and mulatto males.<ref>1860 U.S. Federal Census for Loudoun County, unstated. An indexing problem may exist, for ancestry.com also includes a link to six slaves of William McPherson in Loudoun County's Southern District to William Mason. The 1860 Virginia slave indexes are not available online.</ref>
==Later life== On January 2, 1857, six years after the death of his wife, and at the age of 75, Temple sold Temple Hall to Henry A. Ball for the sum of $50,000 and retired to [[Georgetown, Washington, D.C.|Georgetown]] in Washington, D.C.<ref name="NRHP2"/><ref name=HMDB2/> Temple Mason died in 1862 and was interred in the Old Episcopal Churchyard in Leesburg.<ref name=GH1/><ref name="NRHP2"/>
==Children== Temple and his wife Ann had at least eleven children:<ref name=GH1/> * Temple Anna Mason (1813–June 5, 1849)<ref name=GH1/> * Nicholas Carroll Mason (died May 3, 1873)<ref name=GH1/> * Maria Louisa Mason<ref name=GH1/> * Mary Carter Mason (died 1897)<ref name=GH1/> * Charles Carroll Mason (died August 28, 1866)<ref name=GH1/> * Euphan Mason<ref name=GH1/> * Ann Elizabeth Carroll Thomson Mason Magill (1815–September 13, 1844)<ref name=GH1/> * Westwood Thomson Mason (1819–1853)<ref name=GH1/> * William Temple Thomson Mason, Jr. (1820–December 31, 1891)<ref name=GH1/> * Thomas Henry Carroll Mason (c. 1822–January 28, 1838)<ref name=GH1/> * John Thomson Mason (1827–June 2, 1891)<ref name=GH1/>
==Relations== William Temple Thomson Mason was a nephew of [[George Mason]] (1725–1792);<ref name=GH1/> son of [[Thomson Mason]] (1733–1785);<ref name=GH1/> half-brother of [[Stevens Thomson Mason (Virginia)|Stevens Thomson Mason]] (1760–1803) and [[John Thomson Mason]] (1765–1824);<ref name=GH1/> first cousin of [[George Mason V]] (1753–1796);<ref name=GH1/> first cousin once removed of [[Thomson Francis Mason]] (1785–1838), [[George Mason VI]] (1786–1834), [[Richard Barnes Mason]] (1797–1850), and [[James Murray Mason]] (1798–1871);<ref name=GH1/> uncle of [[Armistead Thomson Mason]] (1787–1819), [[John Thomson Mason (1787–1850)|John Thomson Mason]] (1787–1850), and [[John Thomson Mason, Jr.]] (1815–1873);<ref name=GH1/> and great uncle of [[Stevens T. Mason|Stevens Thomson Mason]] (1811–1843).<ref name=GH1/>
